citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
Two English Bulldogs were identified with eye discharge and corneal abnormalities. An adult female English Bulldog
identified as “Tacovah” (M/C # 900215003833523) was squinting her left eye and had a large amount of thick yellow
discharge. The bottom third of the cornea contained a white cloudy area. The conjunctiva was reddened. The lower eyelid
was rolled in with the eyelashes touching the cornea.
An adult male English Bulldog identified as “Corona” (M/C # 900215003462331) had a large amount of thick yellow
discharge from both eyes. The bottom third of the cornea in the left eye contained a white cloudy area with a raised pink
center. The conjunctiva was swollen and reddened. The conjunctiva of the right eye was swollen and reddened with
visible blood vessels.
The licensee had not observed the corneal abnormalities and no treatment had been administered. Eye problems can
progress rapidly, can be painful, and can result in loss of vision. The licensee must have these dogs evaluated by a
veterinarian for proper diagnosis, must follow the veterinarian's treatment plan, and must follow-up with the veterinarian if
the problem does not resolve in a timely manner. The licensee must keep medical records for the inspector to review
upon request. Correct by the end of business on August 2, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
Marla Renshaw, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER
Leann Sargeant, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
Two English Bulldogs were identified with eye discharge and corneal abnormalities. An adult female English Bulldog 
identified as “Tacovah” (M/C # 900215003833523) was squinting her left eye and had a large amount of thick yellow 
discharge. The bottom third of the cornea contained a white cloudy area. The conjunctiva was reddened. The lower eyelid 
was rolled in with the eyelashes touching the cornea. 
 
An adult male English Bulldog identified as “Corona” (M/C # 900215003462331) had a large amount of thick yellow 
discharge from both eyes. The bottom third of the cornea in the left eye contained a white cloudy area with a raised pink 
center. The conjunctiva was swollen and reddened. The conjunctiva of the right eye was swollen and reddened with 
visible blood vessels.  
 
The licensee had not observed the corneal abnormalities and no treatment had been administered. Eye problems can 
progress rapidly, can be painful, and can result in loss of vision. The licensee must have these dogs evaluated by a 
veterinarian for proper diagnosis, must follow the veterinarian's treatment plan, and must follow-up with the veterinarian if 
the problem does not resolve in a timely manner. The licensee must keep medical records for the inspector to review 
upon request. Correct by the end of business on August 2, 2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Marla Renshaw, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER 
Leann Sargeant, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
